items.title: US and UK not among signatories of Paris AI summit declaration
items.summary:
- The US and UK have not signed the Paris AI summit’s declaration on artificial intelligence.
- The declaration emphasizes AI being open, inclusive, transparent, ethical, safe, secure, and trustworthy.
- The Élysée Palace mentioned that more countries might sign the declaration after the event.

items.title: How Meta abandoned Silicon Valley’s most ambitious diversity goals
items.summary:
- In 2019, [Facebook](https://pollinations.ai/referral?topic=facebook) aimed for 50% diverse workforce by 2024.
- Meta announced end to diversity goals just after 2024.
- DEI programs, once a priority, have been abandoned.
- CEO [Mark Zuckerberg](https://pollinations.ai/referral?topic=markzuckerberg) shifted goals for ‘free expression’ over DEI.
- Former Facebook diversity officer Maxine Williams reassigned.
- Recent policy changes allow derogatory terms against marginalized groups.

items.title: Campaigner for migrants in Libya says his phone was targeted in spyware attack
items.author: Not given
items.summary:
- David Yambio, a human rights activist, revealed his phone was targeted by spyware, as informed by Apple.
- He is a critic of Italy's migrant pact with Libya and involved with evidence collection for the ICC.
- Yambio received a notification on November 13 about a mercenary spyware attack potentially targeting him personally.
- An investigation is ongoing by Citizen Lab regarding the spyware targeting activists and journalists in Italy.
- Yambio's case raises concerns about political implications and the safety of ICC witnesses.

items.title: AI chatbots distort and mislead when asked about current affairs, BBC finds
items.author: Not given
items.summary:
- Leading AI assistants like ChatGPT, Copilot, Gemini, and Perplexity create distortions and inaccuracies when responding to current affairs.
- Over 50% of AI-generated answers showed significant issues according to BBC research.
- Errors included misstatements about politicians' positions and incorrect health advice from the NHS.
- 20% of responses had factual errors; 13% of sourced quotes were incorrect or fabricated.
- BBC's Deborah Turness warned about the risks of AI tools undermining public trust in facts.

items.title: Elon Musk-led group makes surprise bid of nearly $100bn for OpenAI
items.summary:
- Elon Musk leads a consortium that has submitted a bid of $97.4bn for OpenAI's assets.
- The bid complicates OpenAI's transition away from its original non-profit status.
- Musk, a co-founder of OpenAI, is in a feud with CEO Sam Altman over company direction and has previously sued over restructuring plans.
- The consortium includes investment firms and aims to ensure fair compensation for charitable assets taken by OpenAI's leadership.
- OpenAI plans to complete its restructuring by 2026 to stay competitive in AI innovation.

items.title: Revelations of Israeli spyware abuse raise fears over possible use by Trump
items.summary:
- WhatsApp reported that 90 users, including journalists and activists, were targeted by spyware from Paragon Solutions last year.
- Paragon's spyware, Graphite, can hack phones to access sensitive information, underlining risks of abuse by governments.
- The US has previously engaged with similar spyware, raising concerns of potential misuse, especially related to political surveillance under Trump's administration.

items.title: The Sims: A Darker Perspective on a Beloved Game
items.summary:
[EA released a rerelease of The Sims 1 and 2 to celebrate the series’ 25th anniversary.](https://variety.com/2025/gaming/news/the-sims-2-rerelease-ea-25th-anniversary-bundle-1236292644/)
[The original games depict a more dystopian and bleak reality compared to the brighter visuals of The Sims 4.](https://www.theguardian.com/games/2025/feb/10/wait-the-sims-is-a-lot-bleaker-than-i-remember)
[Social mobility in The Sims 1 is nearly impossible, reflecting real-world economic struggles and challenges in forming relationships.](https://www.theguardian.com/games/2025/feb/10/wait-the-sims-is-a-lot-bleaker-than-i-remember)

items.title: Want to know how the world ends? Try this Wikipedia page
items.summary:
- The article explores theories of how the universe may end, referencing Wikipedia's 'Timeline of the Far Future'.
- It discusses various speculative future events across centuries, including predictions like the last Bitcoin being mined in 2140 and a 639-year-long performance concluding in 2640.
- The piece reflects on the paradoxical nature of Wikipedia, presenting monumental scientific theories in a simple format, triggering a sense of awe about the vastness of time and the future of humanity.

items.title: Engine of inequality: fears over AI’s global impact dominate Paris summit
items.summary:
- The global summit in Paris discusses AI's effects on environment and inequality, attended by leaders and tech experts.
- Anne Bouverot highlights the unsustainable energy demands of AI while also promoting its potential to mitigate climate change.
- Christy Hoffman warns that AI without worker involvement could exacerbate inequality across democracies.
- Max Tegmark compares the current situation to the film 'Don’t Look Up', stating that awareness of AI's risks is being ignored.
- The Paris gathering, termed the AI action summit, contrasts with the previous AI safety summit in the UK.

items.title: Thousands of Artists Demand Cancellation of AI Art Auction, Claiming Mass Theft
items.summary:
- Thousands of artists are petitioning Christie’s to cancel the Augmented Intelligence auction set for February 20, 2025.
- The auction includes 20 lots priced between $10,000 and $250,000, featuring art from notable creators.
- Over 3,000 signatures on a letter claim that the auction promotes AI models trained on copyrighted works without permission.
- Artists suing AI companies assert that tools like Stable Diffusion exploit their works legally.
- Christie’s spokesperson stated that AI is used in a controlled manner with artists' own inputs.
- Some artists involved in the auction reject the claims, asserting their right to use AI in their work.

items.title: AI race must be led by ‘western, liberal, democratic’ countries, says UK minister
items.author: Peter Kyle
items.summary:
- The UK technology secretary emphasizes the need for 'western, liberal, democratic' countries to lead the AI race before the global AI summit in Paris.
- Peter Kyle discusses concerns regarding China's rising influence in AI, particularly with the emergence of the new Chinese company DeepSeek.
- The AI Action Summit on February 10-11 will include political leaders and tech executives from around the world, discussing jobs, culture, and global governance in AI development.

items.title: Tech firms call for zonal electricity pricing in UK to fuel AI datacentres
items.summary:
- Tech companies, including Amazon and OpenAI, urge the UK government to implement zonal electricity pricing to support AI datacentre growth in remote areas.
- A report by the Social Market Foundation suggests that zonal pricing would lead to significantly cheaper electricity in areas with ample supply, like Scotland, making them attractive for datacentres.
- The report estimates that datacentre electricity costs could be 65% lower in Aberdeen compared to Slough due to zonal pricing.
- The proposal comes amidst scepticism regarding the UK's high industrial electricity prices and its commitment to phasing out fossil fuels by 2030.
- The report recommends additional measures to accelerate AI datacentre development, such as enhancing grid connections for low-carbon energy and reducing planning delays.
- Government decisions on electricity market reforms are anticipated in the coming months, amidst divided industry opinions on the proposal.

items.title: Greens say Labor must slash NBN chief’s salary in exchange for support on anti-privatisation bill
items.summary:
- The Greens demand a salary cut for the NBN CEO in exchange for supporting a bill to prevent future privatisation of the network.
- Proposed amendments include a salary cap for executives and ensuring NBN services remain affordable and accessible.
- Current CEO Stephen Rue earned $2.85m, prompting calls for a cap of around $500,084 based on average earnings.
- New CEO Ellie Sweeney may face a pay cut of approximately $2.5m if the amendments are enacted.
- Greens senator Sarah Hanson-Young criticized the current salary as "obscene" amid a cost-of-living crisis.
- Labor needs support from the Greens and other crossbenchers to pass the bill, as the Coalition opposes it.

items.title: From Dogecoin to $Trump: everything you need know about the wild world of meme coins
items.summary:
- Donald Trump launched the meme coin $Trump days before his inauguration, initially soaring from $7 to $75 before falling to about $40.
- Meme coins, like Dogecoin, are digital assets based on internet memes, mostly used for speculation and often short-lived.
- The market for meme coins has grown, driven by social media trends and disillusioned investors, despite the risks of losing money through schemes like 'pump and dump'.
- No regulatory framework exists, leading to potential issues for investors, as most meme coins don't have sustainable value.
- Meme coins often reference internet culture, and their phenomenon has been compared to the previous NFT bubble.
- Users may buy coins like $Trump not only for speculation but also to show support for the former president, despite concerns over conflicts of interest in trading fees.

items.title: Google Maps changed the way we get around. It all began in a spare bedroom in Sydney
items.author: Stephen Ma
items.summary:
- Google Maps was launched on 8 February 2005 and has over 2 billion monthly users.
- It started as a project named Where 2 Technologies, founded by Stephen Ma and three others in Sydney.
- Google acquired Where 2 in 2004, leading to the debut of Google Maps months later.
- The development involved creating a web version using AJAX for dynamic map updates.
- Stephen Ma emphasizes collaboration and recognizes the contributions of others alongside his own.

items.title: Revealed: gambling firms secretly sharing users’ data with Facebook without permission
items.summary:
- Gambling companies are allegedly sharing users' data with Facebook without consent, violating data protection laws.
- The data is used by Meta to profile users as gamblers and target them with ads.
- Testing revealed that 52 out of 150 gambling websites, including Hollywoodbets and Sporting Index, shared data automatically without explicit consent.
- Data sharing was found to occur before users could agree or decline marketing consent.
- Calls for regulatory intervention were made by politicians, highlighting inadequate controls in the gambling industry.
- The ICO has been reviewing tracking pixels and enforcing compliance with data protection laws, amid previous reports of misuse.

items.title: Who is helping Elon Musk gut the US government?
items.summary:
- Elon Musk's efforts to defund and depopulate the federal government are causing chaos in US politics.
- His team, called Doge, consists of wealthy executives, far-right ideologues, and young engineers.
- Key agencies affected include the US Department of Treasury, GSA, and USAID, with access to sensitive data reportedly gained.
- Musk's governance led by loyalists lacking government experience, raising questions about legality and ethics.
- The team has faced allegations of withholding identities and evading scrutiny during interviews with federal employees.
- Musk appears to have high independence in running Doge with support from Donald Trump.
- Key figures from Musk's ventures, such as Steve Davis and Amanda Scales, are leading the initiative.
- Young engineers with little experience are also being given significant responsibilities.
- The group's operations are said to be influenced by far-right politicians like Marjorie Taylor Greene.
- Doge's spokesperson is Katie Miller, connected to Stephen Miller, a prominent figure in the Trump administration.

items.title: PlayStation Network outage leads to rush of complaints from gamers
items.summary:
- The PlayStation Network (PSN) outage started in the UK around midnight on Friday, preventing access to online gaming events for players worldwide.
- Approximately 71,000 gamers reported issues, affecting online gaming lobbies, the PlayStation Store, and user accounts.
- The outage impacts major gaming events like weekend league matches in FC 25 and promotional events for Call of Duty, frustrating many users who expressed their dissatisfaction on social media.
- Sony has acknowledged the issue and is working to resolve it as quickly as possible.

items.title: What does Elon Musk believe?
items.summary:
- Elon Musk has aligned himself with far-right politics, raising questions about his beliefs and intent.
- He has controversially disbanded agencies like USAid, claiming corruption.
- Musk has recruited young tech workers for government roles, bypassing typical clearances.
- His actions affect government efficiency and workforce, encouraging mass resignations.
- Musk's views fluctuate, supporting both basic income and anti-union stances, often intertwining with personal business interests.
- Personal matters, particularly involving his daughter and identity politics, have influenced his political shifts.

items.title: Judge temporarily blocks Musk’s ‘Doge’ team from accessing treasury records
items.summary:
- A federal judge blocked Elon Musk’s 'Doge' team from accessing treasury department records containing sensitive personal data.
- The preliminary injunction was issued after a lawsuit by 19 Democratic attorneys general against the Trump administration.
- The lawsuit alleges unauthorized access to the treasury department’s payment system, violating federal law.
- The payment system is crucial for managing tax refunds and benefits for millions of Americans.
- The judge ordered immediate destruction of any downloaded sensitive information by unauthorized individuals.
- A hearing has been set for February 14.
- New York AG Letitia James expressed security concerns and potential illegal financial freezes due to Doge’s access to treasury data.
- Critics worry about Musk's influence on government spending and data access, while supporters argue it's for efficiency.
- The lawsuit claims the Doge's actions could interfere with Congress-approved funding and violate legal data protection obligations.

items.title: Elon Musk put a chip in this paralysed man’s brain. Now he can move things with his mind. Should we be amazed - or terrified?
items.author: Not given
items.summary:
• In June 2016, Noland Arbaugh was paralyzed after an accident while swimming.
• In January 2024, he became the first human recipient of a Neuralink brain-computer interface, enabling him to control a computer with his mind.
• Noland can now play chess, browse the internet, and play video games without physical movement, using the N1 chip implanted in his brain.

items.title: Trump Administration Suspends $5bn Electric Vehicle Charging Program
items.summary:
- The Trump administration ordered US states to suspend a $5bn electric vehicle charging station program.
- The Federal Highway Administration issued a memo stating no allocation funds under the Biden administration's NEVI program should be spent.
- Emily Biondi, FHWA’s associate administrator, noted that existing guidelines are rescinded and new plans must be approved before new obligations can occur.
- Reimbursements for current obligations will be allowed to maintain financial commitments.
- As of November, there are 126 public charging ports at NEVI stations in nine states, showing an increase in operational EV stations.

items.title: Trump’s meme coin sparks more than 700 copycats posing as official crypto
items.summary:
- Donald Trump launched a controversial meme coin before his second inauguration in January.
- More than 700 copycat meme coins have been created, many using Trump family names without official ties.
- Experts warn that investors are at risk of being deceived by these fake coins.
- The first copycat coin appeared just 29 minutes after the official announcement of the Trump coin.
- Trump's involvement in cryptocurrency has faced criticism from ethics watchdogs and economists for potential grifting.

items.title: Parents sue TikTok over child deaths allegedly caused by ‘blackout challenge’
items.summary:
- Parents of four British teenagers are suing TikTok, alleging their children died from the viral 'blackout challenge'.
- The children, aged between 12 and 14, died in 2022 while attempting this challenge, which gained popularity in 2021.
- The lawsuit, filed by the Social Media Victims Law Center, claims TikTok targeted these children with dangerous content to increase engagement and revenue.
- TikTok asserts it has blocked searches for related content since 2020 and aims to remove dangerous challenges.
- The lawsuit claims TikTok misleads parents into believing the platform is safe for children while pushing hazardous content.
- Previous related lawsuits against TikTok involve other children harmed by dangerous challenges.
- The Online Safety Act in the UK mandates social media protections for minors, coming into effect this year.

items.title: UK demands ability to access Apple users’ encrypted data
items.summary:
- The UK government is demanding Apple create a backdoor in its encrypted cloud service, challenging its privacy stance.
- A technical capability notice under the Investigatory Powers Act requires Apple to assist law enforcement globally.
- Apple's Advanced Data Protection service utilizes end-to-end encryption, meaning only account holders can decrypt files.
- Apple has stated it would refuse to build a backdoor and withdraw security features from the UK market instead.
- The UK government’s demand may lead to conflicts with EU data-sharing agreements.

items.title: Football Manager 25 video game cancelled after series of delays
items.summary:
- Sports Interactive (SI) has cancelled the 2025 release of Football Manager after multiple delays.
- The decision followed technical challenges and an inability to meet the desired player experience and interface standards.
- SI plans to focus on future games, typically released in November, and will not update the 2024 version with 2025 squad information.
- Full refunds will be provided to fans who pre-ordered FM25, in light of the cancellation.

items.title: Call to make tech firms report data centre energy use as AI booms
items.summary:
- Experts urge legal requirements for tech companies to report energy and water use in data centres due to environmental concerns from AI growth.
- A report by the National Engineering Policy Centre (NEPC) emphasizes the environmental risks of unchecked AI expansion and the need for resource-efficient practices.
- Microsoft and Google have reported significant increases in water consumption for data centres in recent years, with Microsoft's 2022 consumption up 34% from 2021.
- The NEPC report advocates for mandatory environmental reporting and setting sustainability standards for data centres to mitigate impacts.

items.title: Amazon ends year on strong note but forecasts weak upcoming quarter
items.summary:
- Amazon reported fourth-quarter 2024 revenue of $187.79bn, exceeding expectations of $187.3bn.
- The earnings amounted to $1.86 per share, surpassing estimates of $1.49.
- Strong holiday season drove an 8.7% year-over-year increase in online spending, totaling $241.1bn according to Adobe Analytics.
- For the upcoming quarter, Amazon forecasts sales between $151bn and $155.5bn, lower than analyst expectations of $158.5bn.
- CEO Andy Jassy highlighted innovations in AI, including the new AI chip Trainium2.
- Cost-cutting measures, including layoffs, have positively impacted Amazon’s financial performance.

items.title: Google edits Super Bowl ad for AI that featured false information
items.summary:
- Google edited an ad for its AI tool Gemini before the Super Bowl after it included false information about gouda cheese.
- The ad claimed gouda accounts for "50% to 60% of global cheese consumption," which was labeled an "AI hallucination" by a blogger.
- Google remade the ad based on feedback from the cheesemonger featured in the clip, removing the false statistic.

items.title: US Immigration is Gaming Google to Create a Mirage of Mass Deportations
items.summary:
- Reports of mass immigration arrests by ICE have been widespread across the US.
- Google searches for recent ICE operations often return outdated press releases marked as current, misleading viewers.
- Instances like a 2010 Colorado operation and an arrest in New Orleans from February 2024 appear as recent news due to manipulated timestamps.
- An immigration lawyer discovered the pattern of outdated press releases showing up high in Google searches, suggesting ICE is gaming the system.
- ICE has not commented on these allegations, while Google states it reflects the last updated date but doesn’t boost rankings based on timestamp changes.
- The tactic appears to be part of a broader strategy to instill fear in immigrant communities amid a crackdown on immigration enforcement.

items.title: Artificial news: How to create an AI anchor – video
items.summary:
- Channel 1 is a new AI-driven rolling news channel, with stories scripted, edited, and presented by AI.
- It supports over 30 languages and can transmit customized news stories rapidly.
- Raises questions about trust in AI news and the appeal of a non-human anchor in journalism.
- The Guardian visited the creators in Los Angeles for insights and auditions.

items.title: Owner of spyware used in alleged WhatsApp breach ends contract with Italy
items.summary:
- Paragon Solutions, linked to spyware used against 90 individuals, ends contract with Italy.
- The termination follows allegations of use against journalists and activists critical of the government.
- Italian Prime Minister Giorgia Meloni's office denies government involvement in the breaches.
- WhatsApp confirmed the number of affected Italians appeared to be seven, amidst concerns over various countries involved.
- Paragon was recently acquired by AE Industrial Partners and had contracts with U.S. agencies, currently under review due to compliance issues.

items.title: Google scraps diversity hiring goals and cites Trump’s DEI orders
items.summary:
- Google is discontinuing its diversity hiring goals and reviewing some of its DEI initiatives.
- The decision aligns with a trend among US businesses, especially in Silicon Valley, to scale back diversity efforts after initial pushes following protests in 2020.
- Google updated its SEC filing, omitting a commitment to diversity, equity, and inclusion that was present in reports from 2021 to 2023.
- The company is reassessing its DEI programs in light of recent court decisions and executive orders from Donald Trump aimed at reducing DEI measures for federal contractors.
- Google's HR head announced the termination of aspirational hiring goals established in 2020 to improve representation.
- Other companies, such as Meta and Amazon, have also ended their DEI programs recently, influenced by pressure from conservative groups and recent legal rulings.

items.title: I loved Pokémon Trading Card Pocket – until I didn’t
items.summary:
- The author enjoyed playing Pokémon Trading Card Pocket daily until quitting after the trading feature was launched.
- Despite completing the collection, the excitement diminished quickly, illustrating the nature of player engagement.
- The article discusses personal feelings around quitting games and the stigma of not finishing games, suggesting it’s okay to stop playing when fun is lost.
- Acknowledges that many players do not complete games, citing studies showing only 15-35% finish any given game.
- Provides a brief list of games the author abandoned near completion and contrasts them with those they continue to enjoy.

items.title: Global ransomware payments plunge by a third amid crackdown
items.summary:
- Ransomware payments fell by over a third to $813m in 2024, down from $1.25bn in 2023.
- Notable ransomware incidents occurred in 2024, including attacks on NHS trusts and Krispy Kreme.
- The decline is attributed to victims refusing to pay and intensified law enforcement actions against cybercriminals.
- The total for 2024 is lower than previous years, even below 2020's $999m and 2019's $1.1bn.
- Cyber threat expert Jacqueline Burns Koven noted the figures suggest averted 'ransomware apocalypse' due to effective collaboration and victim resistance.
- Despite the decline, ransomware attacks remain prevalent, with increases in demands from cyber gangs.
- UK ministers are considering a ban on ransomware payments by public bodies, with proposals requiring reporting of such payments to the government.

items.title: Google owner drops promise not to use AI for weapons
items.summary:
- Alphabet has rescinded its pledge not to use AI for developing weapons and surveillance tools.
- The company updated its ethical guidelines, which no longer mention avoiding technologies that could cause overall harm.
- Google's AI head, Demis Hassabis, stated the guidelines reflect changes in a rapidly evolving world focused on national security.
- A blogpost by Hassabis and senior VP James Manyika emphasizes the need for democracies to lead in AI development, promoting freedom and human rights.
- This change reflects the significant growth of AI, which is now a general-purpose technology used globally.
- Following the announcement, Google shares fell 7.5% in after-hours trading after the company reported lower than expected earnings.

items.title: Kingdom Come: Deliverance 2 review – it’s a hard-knock life in medieval Bohemia
items.summary:
- Life in 16th-century Bohemia is harsh, depicted through the struggles of Henry, a blacksmith-turned-knight.
- The game emphasizes realism, requiring players to manage survival and social interactions carefully, influenced by appearance and hygiene.
- Players can experience a rich role-playing environment with customizable interactions and skill-based progression.
- Kingdom Come: Deliverance 2 encourages exploration and experimentation, contrasting with many modern games that ease gameplay friction.
- The game, priced at £49.99, is noted for its immersive world and challenging gameplay, requiring patience and skill.

items.title: School phone bans do not improve grades or wellbeing, says UK study
items.summary:
- A study from the University of Birmingham found that banning smartphones at school does not improve academic grades or children's wellbeing.
- Increased screen time was linked to lower grades, poor sleep, disruptive behaviour, and lack of exercise, but outcomes were similar in schools with and without phone bans.
- The research indicates that simply banning phones is insufficient; a holistic approach to reduce phone use is necessary for positive mental health outcomes.

items.title: Activists critical of Italian PM may have had their phones targeted by Paragon spyware, says WhatsApp
items.summary:
- Luca Casarini, founder of NGO Mediterranea Saving Humans, revealed his phone was targeted by Paragon spyware.
- WhatsApp identified that 90 journalists and activists were likely compromised by the Israeli company's spyware.
- The activists targeted have been vocal critics of Italian Prime Minister Giorgia Meloni.
- Paragon sells spyware to government agencies, claiming to restrict sales to democratic nations.
- Casarini received a notification about the spyware while on a train, alongside 89 others.
- Paragon's hacking software, Graphite, can access all data on infected phones without user interaction.
- There is increasing scrutiny on Italy's potential use of the spyware, with calls to investigate the users and extent of the issue.
- WhatsApp indicated the surveillance began in December but provided no information on its duration.

items.title: OnePlus 13 review: the rapid Android with a gorgeous fabric back
items.summary:
- The OnePlus 13 is priced at £899 ($899, €1,049) and offers premium features at a slightly lower cost than competitors.
- It features a 6.8-inch QHD+ OLED screen, Snapdragon 8 Elite chip, and 50MP triple rear camera setup.
- Battery life lasts about 50 hours with mixed usage, supports 45W wired and up to 50W wireless charging.
- The design includes a distinctive blue microfibre back with IP68/69 water resistance.
- Oxygen OS 15 runs on Android 15, providing fast performance but has some rough edges and limited AI integration compared to rivals.
- OnePlus promises four years of Android updates and six years of security patches, starting January 7, 2031.
- The camera performs well in various lighting conditions and offers several modes including macro and time-lapse.
- Competitors include Google Pixel 9 Pro, Samsung Galaxy S25+, and iPhone 16 Pro, all starting around £999.

items.title: Google parent Alphabet’s earnings disappoint Wall Street amid stiff AI competition
items.summary:
- Alphabet's shares dropped over 6% after a revenue miss, reporting $96.5 billion against expectations of $96.67 billion.
- Earnings per share (EPS) exceeded expectations at $2.15, surpassing the anticipated $2.13.
- Alphabet reported $84 billion in services revenue and $12 billion in Cloud revenues, marking a 30% year-over-year increase.
- Analysts are focusing on AI spending, Cloud revenue, and competition from companies like DeepSeek and OpenAI.
- There are concerns about Google's competitive edge eroding in 2025 due to antitrust issues and open-source AI models.
- Alphabet plans to spend $75 billion on capital expenditures in the coming year, primarily to enhance AI capabilities.
- The company may need to adjust its approach to AI-integrated advertising due to rising costs and competitive pressures.
- A recent policy change allows Alphabet to develop AI for national security uses, removing a previous pledge against such applications.
- Analysts expect inquiries regarding the ongoing Department of Justice case linked to Google's monopoly in search and advertising.

items.title: How Elon Musk Wields Political Power Over the US Government
items.summary:
- Elon Musk has gained significant political influence by supporting Donald Trump's re-election campaign, investing over $250 million.
- His newly formed ‘Department of Government Efficiency’ (Doge) clashes with federal workers for access to key government systems, resulting in the ousting of several officials.
- Musk aims to dissolve the US Agency for International Development (USAid), claiming corruption without evidence, and has threatened those opposing his agenda.
- Following Trump's inauguration, Musk’s team has rapidly taken over multiple government agencies, creating chaos and confusion among employees.
- The operational legitimacy of Doge is questioned, with lawsuits filed against its activities and authority over federal agencies.

items.title: AI ‘godfather’ predicts another revolution in the tech in next five years
items.author: Yann LeCun, Yoshua Bengio
items.summary:
- Yann LeCun, chief AI scientist at Meta, predicts a revolution in AI by the end of the decade due to current system limitations.
- Recent advancements heightened expectations for AI reaching human-level intelligence, but LeCun emphasizes significant challenges remain.
- The Queen Elizabeth prize for engineering was awarded to seven engineers for contributions to machine learning, highlighting its importance in AI development.

items.title: How Trump’s Tariff Will Impact Fast-Fashion Fans
items.summary:
- Donald Trump’s 10% tariff on China-made goods took effect recently, affecting shopping habits of fast-fashion enthusiasts.
- The tariff closes the 'de minimus' loophole that allowed duty-free shipping for packages under $800, expected to lead to price hikes at Temu and Shein.
- Shoppers are worried about the impact on their retail experiences, with many rushing to place orders before potential increases.

items.title: Does AI need all that money? (Tech giants say yes)
items.summary:
- DeepSeek's claim that AI shouldn't be expensive led to a $600bn drop in Nvidia's market cap in one day.
- DeepSeek claims to have trained its AI model with just $5.6m, challenging the substantial investments by firms like Meta ($60bn) and Microsoft ($80bn).
- Microsoft and Meta continue to emphasize their heavy investments in AI as strategic advantages amidst criticisms of overspending.
- OpenAI plans to release a new version of ChatGPT with enhanced capabilities for free, maintaining its high spending levels despite market fluctuations.

items.title: DeepSeek banned from Australian government devices over national security concerns
items.summary:
- DeepSeek, a Chinese AI chatbot, is banned from all federal government devices in Australia due to national security risks.
- The directive was signed by the home affairs department secretary after intelligence agency advice.
- The Albanese government emphasizes protective actions regarding national security and potential threats posed by AI technologies.
- Australia joins other countries like Taiwan and Italy in banning DeepSeek from government devices.
- Similar to previous bans on TikTok, discussions and considerations regarding DeepSeek's risks are ongoing within government systems.

items.title: The 15 best PlayStation 5 games to play in 2025
items.summary:
- Sony's PlayStation 5 has produced top-quality games since its launch, with both in-house and indie developers showcasing their creativity.
- Notable PS5 games include:
  - **Astro Bot**: A platformer featuring a space robot on a quest to reassemble his ship.
  - **Baldur’s Gate 3**: Celebrated as a modern RPG landmark, offers a deep narrative akin to tabletop gaming.
  - **Cocoon**: An innovative puzzle game featuring inter-world traversal.
  - **Death Stranding**: Known for its unique narrative and delivery mechanics in a post-apocalyptic setting.
  - **Demon’s Souls**: A remastered classic offering a dark and challenging gaming experience.
  - **Elden Ring**: A large open-world game from the makers of Dark Souls, praised for its design.
  - **Final Fantasy VII Remake**: A reimagining of the iconic RPG with updated visuals and gameplay.
  - **God of War Ragnarök**: The sequel that explores mythological themes and character depth.
  - **Gran Turismo 7**: Features stunning graphics and details for vehicle enthusiasts.
  - **Helldivers 2**: A co-op shooter drawing inspiration from science-fiction classics.
  - **The Last of Us Parts I and II Remastered**: Offers updated graphics and a compelling narrative.
  - **Marvel’s Spider-Man 2**: Features a collaborative narrative between Peter Parker and Miles Morales against iconic villains.

items.title: 'I'm a bit lost now': Daisy the AI bot speaks to scammer – video
items.summary:
- O2 has launched an AI bot named Daisy to combat phone scammers.
- Daisy is designed to waste scammers' time by acting confused and reminiscing.
- The initiative illustrates the potential of AI in fighting fraud.

items.title: China unveils US tariffs and Google investigation in response to Trump levies
items.summary:
- Donald Trump imposed 10% tariffs on China, prompting retaliatory actions from Beijing.
- China launched an anti-trust investigation into Google and announced various tariffs on US exports including coal and crude oil.
- Export controls were imposed on critical minerals, and US companies PVH Group and Illumina were added to China's unreliable entity list.
- The US scrapped an exemption for exports valued under $800, affecting popular Chinese retailers.
- Trump postponed tariffs on Mexico and Canada after negotiations, amid global economic concerns.

items.title: 'Dear, did you say pastry?': meet the ‘AI granny’ driving scammers up the wall
items.summary:
- An AI bot named 'Daisy' simulates an elderly grandmother to frustrate phone scammers.
- Daisy uses ambivalence and confusion to waste the fraudsters' time, engaging them in conversations about knitting and pastries.
- The initiative aims to raise awareness about scams rather than rolling out the AI widely, with the potential for future versions to adopt different accents and personas.
